subject: linear_algebra
title: Linear Transformations: Definition and Linearity Conditions
contentHtml: A linear transformation is a fundamental concept in linear algebra that has far-reaching implications in machine learning and artificial intelligence.

problem.statementHtml: Given a linear transformation T: \mathbf{R}^2 \to \mathbf{R}^3, determine if it is linear.
problem.solutionHtml:
To show that T is linear, we need to demonstrate that it satisfies two properties:

  • Linearity in the first variable: \(T(c\mathbf{x} + d\mathbf{y}) = cT(\mathbf{x}) + dT(\mathbf{y})\)
  • Linearity in the second variable: \(T(\mathbf{x} + c\mathbf{y}) = T(\mathbf{x}) + cT(\mathbf{y})\)

workedExample.problemHtml: Consider the matrix A = \[\begin{bmatrix}1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4\end{bmatrix}\]. Determine if the transformation T(\mathbf{x}) = A\mathbf{x} is linear.

steps.description: Check linearity in the first variable
steps.explanation: We can see that T is linear in the first variable because it only scales and adds vectors.

steps.description: Check linearity in the second variable
steps.explanation: Similarly, T is linear in the second variable because it only scales and adds vectors.
Since T satisfies both linearity conditions, we can conclude that it is a linear transformation.

intuition: Linear transformations are essential in machine learning as they allow us to map inputs to outputs while preserving the original structure.
visualDescription: A diagram showing the mapping of vectors under a linear transformation would be helpful for visualizing the concept.
commonMistakes: Forgetting one of the linearity conditions
realWorldApplications: Linear transformations are used in neural networks to map inputs to outputs.
